summary: Coastal, Great Lakes, and inland ports are critical to the U.S. economy. Aside from moving freight, ports across the U.S. have a variety of non-freight activities—like cruise ship and ferry terminals, commercial fishing, recreation, and commercial and residential development. Ports engage in non-freight activities to diversify business, find new uses for underused facilities, and contribute to community development. Federal grant programs we reviewed provided some...
title: Maritime Infrastructure: Public Ports Engage in an Extensive Range of Activities beyond Freight Movement
